sub_topic: Calculating the boiling and melting points of inorganic compounds
message_1: What is the boiling point of sodium chloride (NaCl) when it is dissolved in water at a concentration of 0.1 mol/L?
message_2:
To determine the boiling point of a sodium chloride (NaCl) solution with a concentration of 0.1 mol/L, we can use the boiling point elevation formula:

ΔTb = Kb × m × i

where ΔTb is the boiling point elevation, Kb is the ebullioscopic constant of water (0.512°C·kg/mol), m is the molality of the solution, and i is the van't Hoff factor (which is 2 for NaCl, as it dissociates into two ions: Na+ and Cl-).

First, we need to convert the concentration (0.1 mol/L) to molality. Molality is defined as moles of solute per kilogram of solvent. Assuming the density of water is 1 g/mL, 1 L of water weighs 1000 g or 1 kg. Thus, the molality of the solution is also 0.1 mol/kg.

Now, we can use the formula:

ΔTb = (0.512°C·kg/mol) × (0.1 mol/kg) × 2
ΔTb = 0.1024°C

The boiling point elevation is 0.1024°C. Since the normal boiling point of water is 100°C, the boiling point of the 0.1 mol/L NaCl solution is:

100°C + 0.1024°C = 100.1024°C

So, the boiling point of the NaCl solution at a concentration of 0.1 mol/L is approximately 100.1°C.
